raw_text:
Spears seeks aborted tour payment
 
 Singer Britney Spears is suing eight insurance companies that have refused to reimburse her for cancelling her 2004 world tour.
 
 The pop star cancelled her Onyx Hotel tour last June after suffering a knee injury during a video shoot. She is now seeking to be reimbursed for the tour's £5m ($9.3m) costs in a claim filed at New York State Supreme Court. Seven London-based companies and an eighth Paris firm have been given up to 30 days to respond to the complaint.
 
 The 22-year-old star initially missed a number of shows on the 82-date tour after injuring her knee during a show in Illinois last March. But she was rushed to hospital and needed surgery after a later incident while filming a video for her song Outrageous, leading her to cancel the rest of the tour, including dates in China. "She obviously took a wrong step and blew out her knee," a Jive spokeswoman said at the time. "It was an old dance injury." The legal submission described Spears as "one of the most recognised performers in her industry". The Onyx Hotel tour was cited as "a highly crafted production which included the well-known music and dancing of Spears, supported by elaborate costumes, complex choreography as well as cutting-edge video production, lighting and other effects". In September Spears married Kevin Federline, who had been a dancer on the aborted tour.
llama3.2:1b: Britney Spears is suing eight insurance companies for refusing to reimburse her £5m ($9.3m) costs for cancelling her 2004 world tour due to a knee injury sustained during a video shoot. The incident occurred in June 2004, and Spears initially missed several shows on the tour after the injury.
llama3.2:3b: Britney Spears is suing eight insurance companies for not reimbursing her £5m in costs for cancelling her 2004 Onyx Hotel tour due to knee injuries during a video shoot. The tour was cancelled after Spears initially missed several shows and required surgery, with the incident described as an "old dance injury".
gemma2:2b: Britney Spears is suing eight insurance companies for refusing to reimburse her for canceling her 2004 Onyx Hotel Tour due to knee injuries. The singer claims she incurred £5 million in costs and is seeking reimbursement.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Britney Spears, 22-year-old singer, is suing eight insurance companies for £5 million in compensation after canceling her 2004 Onyx Hotel world tour to prevent reimbursement of the tour's costs, including expenses incurred from a knee injury she sustained during filming. The injured pop star initially planned to miss several shows on her 82-date Onyx Hotel tour due to a knee injury and then cancelled most of it after injuring herself again. She then rescheduled some tours with different dates, including one for China. Her wife, Kevin Federline, is also involved in the lawsuit.
The lawsuit highlights Spears' status as "one of the most recognised performers in her industry" and mentions the highly crafted Onyx Hotel tour she was part of, which included her well-known music and dancing, complex choreography, elaborate costumes, cutting-edge video production, lighting effects, and other artistic elements.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Singer Britney Spears sues eight insurance companies over unpaid £5 million cost for cancelled 2004 world tour.
qwen2.5:3b: Britney Spears is suing eight insurance companies for not reimbursing her £5m ($9.3m) cancelled 2004 world tour due to knee injury. The singer initially missed several shows in March but needed surgery after filming issues and canceled the remaining tour, including Chinese dates. She claims she was one of the most recognised performers with a production supported by elaborate costumes and effects. Spears is now seeking reimbursement from companies based in London and Paris for her cancelled £5m world tour.
opencoder:1.5b: The text provided discusses details about Britney Spears' case involving her cancellation of her world tour. The main issue is an injury to the user's knee during a video shoot, and the companies that refused reimbursement have been given up on time to respond. It also mentions seven companies and an eighth Paris firm, all of whom have been set to comply with the claim after 30 days. The loss of her performance is mentioned as "a highly crafted production". She had a wrong step during the filming process, leading to cancellation of the rest of the tour.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize the given text. Let me read through it carefully.

So, Britney Spears is suing eight insurance companies for not reimbursing her for cancelling her 2004 tour because she had a knee injury from a video shoot in Illinois. She's seeking $5 million and is going to New York State Supreme Court. Seven companies are giving up to 30 days each.

The tour was initially missed by 82 shows after her injury, but later there were other issues that forced her to cancel most of the tour dates, including China. The Jive company described her as a leading performer and their production included all her music and video effects. 

Hmm, I need to keep only the key points: Spears is suing insurance companies for failing to reimburse for the tour cancellation due to injury, her claim at New York State Supreme Court, seven companies with up to 30 days to respond, details about her injury, the number of shows missed, and the mention that she had a video shoot in Illinois. Also, some specific information like her age, where she was injured, etc.

I should make sure I include all these elements without adding extra info.
</think>

Spears seeks insurance reimbursement for tour cancellation due to injury, claims at New York State Supreme Court, seven companies with up to 30 days response, tour description as highly crafted production, Jive company citation.
tinyllama:1.1b: Singer Britney Spears is suing eight insurance companies for refusing to reimburse her for canceling her Onyx Hotel tour in 2004 after suffering an injury during a video shoot. The pop star was forced to postpone the 82-date tour in March after injuring herself, undergoing surgery and missing subsequent shows, including ones in China. Spears claims that she was "one of the most recognizable performers" in her industry and cites the $9.3m cost of canceling the tour as proof that she deserves compensation for expenses. The legal submission accuses insurers of being irresponsible and failing to pay fair reimbursement, citing a number of factors including the "intense promotional activities" associated with the tour.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Britney Spears has filed a claim against eight insurance companies for refusing to reimburse her for cancelling her world tour in 2004. She is suing for £5m ($9.3m) in damages, arguing that the insurers were responsible for paying out on her cancelled shows. The lawsuit was filed at New York State Supreme Court, and seven London-based companies and an eighth Paris firm have been given 30 days to respond.

reference: The pop star cancelled her Onyx Hotel tour last June after suffering a knee injury during a video shoot.The Onyx Hotel tour was cited as "a highly crafted production which included the well-known music and dancing of Spears, supported by elaborate costumes, complex choreography as well as cutting-edge video production, lighting and other effects".Singer Britney Spears is suing eight insurance companies that have refused to reimburse her for cancelling her 2004 world tour.In September Spears married Kevin Federline, who had been a dancer on the aborted tour.The 22-year-old star initially missed a number of shows on the 82-date tour after injuring her knee during a show in Illinois last March.
